PENNSYLVANIA'S COASTAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM CONTINUES TO PROVIDE COORDINATED RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, PROTECTION AND DEVELOPMENT OVERSIGHT TO ITS TWO WIDELY SEPARATED LAKE ERIE AND DELAWARE ESTUARY COASTAL ZONES. THE 77-MILE LONG LAKE ERIE COASTAL ZONE IS LOCATED IN THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF PENNSYLVANIA BETWEEN THE OHIO AND NEW YORK STATE LINES. THREE HUNDRED AND FIFTY MILES AWAY ON THE SOUTHEAST BORDER OF PENNSYLVANIA IS THE 112-MILE DELAWARE ESTUARY COASTAL ZONE, STRETCHING FROM THE BOROUGH OF MORRISVILLE IN THE NORTH TO THE BOROUGH OF MARCUS HOOK IN THE SOUTH. BOTH COASTAL ZONES PROVIDE IMPORTANT PORT FACILITIES, RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND UNIQUE NATURAL AND HISTORIC RESOURCES. CONCURRENTLY, EACH AREA POSES UNIQUE SHORELINE MANAGEMENT CHALLENGES SUCH AS BLUFF AND SHORELINE EROSION WITHIN THE LAKE ERIE COASTAL ZONE AND FLOODPLAIN/STORMWATER MANAGEMENT AND WETLANDS PROTECTION THROUGHOUT THE DENSELY POPULATED DELAWARE ESTUARY COASTAL ZONE. STATE AND LOCAL MANAGEMENT OF OREGON'S BEACHES AND DUNES ARE BASED ON REGIONAL MAPPING ORIGINALLY UNDERTAKEN IN 1975. MUCH HAS CHANGED ALONG THE OREGON COAST OVER THE PAST 45 YEARS IN THESE SENSITIVE AND DYNAMIC AREAS. UPDATED INVENTORIES ARE GREATLY NEEDED, ESPECIALLY GIVEN ADDED PRESSURES FROM DEVELOPMENT AND CLIMATE IMPACTS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL SERVE TO CREATE UPDATED MAPPING, OUTREACH, AND POLICY TOOLS TO ENHANCE THE PROTECTION OF OREGON'S BEACH AND DUNE AREAS, WHILE REDUCING EXPOSURE OF LIFE AND PROPERTY TO COASTAL HAZARDS. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS WORK, THE OCMP AND PROJECT TEAM WILL: DEVELOP A NEW GENERATION OF BEACH AND DUNE MAPS AND CHANGE ANALYSIS FOR THE OREGON COAST; CREATE A SUITE OF OUTREACH AND EDUCATIONAL TOOLS ABOUT THE UNIQUE ECOLOGY AND HISTORY OF BEACHES AND DUNES FOR DIVERSE AUDIENCES; SUPPORT UPDATES TO LAND USE PLANNING PROGRAMS ADDRESSING CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES IN BEACHES AND DUNE FOR TWO LOCAL JURISDICTIONS; AND UPDATE POLICY GUIDANCE FOR ALL L

THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT WOULD IDENTIFY MECHANISMS TO ALLOW FOR THE FACILITATION OF MANAGED RETREAT BY REGULATORY OR VOLUNTARY MEANS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WOULD FOCUS ON AN ANALYSIS OF LEGAL AND POLICY AMENDMENTS OR DEVELOPMENT OF NEW POLICIES AS AN ADDITIONAL STEP FROM PRIOR HCZMP ANALYSES TO FURTHER INFORM STATE AND COUNTY CONSIDERATIONS TO IMPLEMENT MANAGED RETREAT. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE (I) AN ANALYSIS OF EXISTING LAND USE POLICIES AND ORDINANCES THAT ARE PRESENTLY IN PLACE, (II) THE RECOMMENDATION OF NEW POLICIES OR PROGRAMS, AND (III) AN ANALYSIS OF HOW AMENDED OR NEW POLICIES OR PROGRAMS WOULD APPLY IN TWO CASE STUDIES. THE ULTIMATE OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT IS TO ASSESS MANAGED RETREAT FROM A LEGAL AND POLICY STANDPOINT WITH A DIRECT APPLICATION TO AREAS THAT ARE PRESENTLY EXPERIENCING SEVERE EROSION. THE CITY OF TYBEE ISLAND IS PROGRESSIVE WHEN IT COMES TO PLANNING FOR THE FUTURE. THE CITY CURRENTLY HAS A BEACH MANAGEMENT PLAN (UPDATED IN 2016), A SEA LEVEL RISE ADAPTATION PLAN (2016), A STORMWATER MASTER DRAINAGE PLAN (UPDATED IN 2021), AND A NFWF FUNDED COASTAL MARSH COMMUNITY RESILIENCE ADAPTATION PROJECT FOR THE BACK BARRIER SIDE OF THE ISLAND (TO BE COMPLETED APRIL 2022). THESE PLANS FOCUS ON SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF MANAGING TYBEE'S NATURAL AND BUILT ASSETS, HOWEVER, SOME PLANS ARE OUTDATED, AND FEW PLANS OUTLINE RESILIENCY MEASURES.  THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO COMBINE THE ABOVE-MENTIONED DOCUMENTS INTO A CCRP TO IMPLEMENT PROJECTS THROUGH THE LENS OF SEA LEVEL RISE AND CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITIES, AS WELL AS NBI AND GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE OPPORTUNITIES, AND RECENTLY COMPLETED MODEL RESILIENCE ORDINANCES DEVELOPED IN THE 309 FY 2016-2020 PROJECT "ENHANCING COASTAL RESILIENCE WITH GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE". THE GCMP'S STRATEGY ALSO CALLS FOR A COMPREHENSIVE

THE EQUITABLE SHORELINE PUBLIC ACCESS PROJECT WILL FURTHER ENHANCE THE RHODE ISLAND COASTAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT COUNCIL'S (CRMC) ABILITY TO PROVIDE EQUITABLE PUBLIC ACCESS TO COASTAL AREAS ACROSS THE STATE. ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITIES HAVE NOT BEEN HISTORICALLY WELL-SERVED BY THE STATE'S EXISTING COASTAL PUBLIC ACCESS SITES. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE CRMC WILL PARTNER WITH RHODE ISLAND SEA GRANT AND THE NARRAGANSETT BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE TO ASSESS THE PUBLIC ACCESS NEEDS OF UNDERSERVED AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITIES. THE RESULTS OF THE NEEDS ASSESSMENT WILL INFORM DEVELOPMENT OF NEW INTERNAL GUIDANCE FOR CRMC STAFF AND COUNCIL MEMBERS TO ENSURE MORE EQUITABLE AND SOCIALLY CONSCIOUS DESIGNATION AND PROTECTION OF PUBLIC ACCESS RIGHTS-OF-WAY. THE INFORMATION WILL ALSO INFORM THE CRMC'S BROADER EFFORTS TO EXPAND AND ENHANCE SHORELINE PUBLIC ACCESS TO ADDRESS THE GROWING NEEDS OF THE STATE.

NOAA IS PROPOSING TO PROVIDE $250,000 IN FEDERAL FUNDS TO THE MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO SUPPORT THE PROJECT ENTITLED, "FLOOD RISK VISUALIZATIONS FOR MARYLAND'S COASTAL COMMUNITIES" FOR THE PERIOD 1 OCTOBER 2022 - 31 MARCH 2024. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THREE PRIMARY OUTCOMES:  1) CONVENING A TECHNICAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO DEVELOP AN UNDERSTANDABLE AND USEFUL FLOOD RISK VULNERABILITY METHODOLOGY USING EXISTING DATA AND TOOLS; 2) ENGAGING SELECTED COASTAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS VIA TARGETED OUTREACH TO PROVIDE FEEDBACK AND TEST THE USABILITY OF THE VISUALIZATIONS; AND 3) COMPLETING DEVELOPMENT OF THE ASSESSMENT TOOL AND FLOOD VISUALIZATIONS FOR VARIOUS FUTURE YEARS, INCLUDING 2020, 2050, 2080 AND 2100, FOR USE BY MARYLAND'S COASTAL COMMUNITIES IN PLANNING ACTIVITIES.

AS THE NHDES COASTAL PROGRAM (NHCP) EMBARKS ON IMPLEMENTING ITS 2021-2025 SECTION 309 COASTAL HAZARDS ENHANCEMENT AREA STRATEGY TO DEVELOP A VISION AND ACTION PLANS FOR COASTAL RESILIENCE IN NH, NHCP STAFF AND COASTAL NETWORK PARTNERS ARE GRAPPLING WITH HOW BEST TO INTEGRATE DIVERSITY, EQUITY, INCLUSION, JUSTICE, AND ACCESSIBILITY (DEIJA) PRINCIPLES INTO THE VISION, ACTION PLANS, AND BROADER COASTAL MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND PRACTICES, AS WELL AS HOW TO ADDRESS SERIOUS GAPS IN LOCAL OPERATIONAL CAPACITY FOR ADVANCING COASTAL RESILIENCE EFFORTS. PROJECT RECAP SEEKS TO ESTABLISH A REPLICABLE MODEL FOR (1) ADVANCING AND FOSTERING DEIJA IN COASTAL MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS IN NH; AND (2) BUILDING LOCAL OPERATIONAL CAPACITY TO ADVANCE TRANSFORMATIVE COASTAL RESILIENCE EFFORTS. TO DO SO, NHCP WILL WORK WITH CORE PARTNERS AT THE GREAT BAY NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (GBNERR), AND ITS NON-PROFIT FRIENDS GROUP, THE GREAT BAY STEWARDS (GBS), TO ENGAGE ORGANIZATIONS THAT WORK WITH UNDERSERVED COM

THIS PROJECT WILL USE A NOVEL ITERATIVE PROCESS TO ASSESS, PLAN, AND EVALUATE THE ABILITY TO INCORPORATE SUSTAINABLE RESILIENT REMEDIATION IN THE LOWER CHRISTINA AND BRANDYWINE RIVERS AS PART OF THE MULTI-PARTNERED CHRISTINA & BRANDYWINE RIVERS REMEDIATION, RESTORATION AND RESILIENCE (CBR4) INITIATIVE (APPENDIX A: CBR4 MAP AND INFORMATION). IT WILL USE MODELS TO SIMULATE THE EXPECTED IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND SEA LEVEL RISE ON CONTAMINATED SITES WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA, INCLUDING SITES WITH EXISTING REMEDIAL ACTIONS. THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING ONGOING FUNDING THROUGH THE NATIONAL COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM TO THE STATE OF  WISCONSIN TO HELP ADMINISTER THE STATE'S FEDERALLY APPROVED COASTAL MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.  THE NATIONAL COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, UNDER THE COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT ACT, IS AN IMPORTANT VOLUNTARY FEDERAL-STATE PARTNERSHIP THAT PROTECTS, RESTORES, AND RESPONSIBLY DEVELOPS OUR NATION'S COASTAL COMMUNITIES AND RESOURCES BY BALANCING ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, COASTAL USES, AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION.  NOAA'S INVESTMENT OF OVER $2.5M IS LEVERAGING OVER $2.4M IN STATE AND LOCAL FUNDS. 

THESE FUNDS WILL SUPPORT JOBS AND PROVIDE CONTINUED ASSISTANCE TO THE WISCONSIN COASTAL MANAGEMENT PROGRAM TO ADDRESS MANY IMPORTANT COASTAL ISSUES IN THE STATE INCLUDING WETLAND PROTECTION, HABITAT RESTORATION, PUBLIC ACCESS, LAND ACQUISITION, NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL, LAND USE AND COMMUNITY PLANNING, NATURAL HAZARDS, AND GREAT LAKES EDUCATION. FOR EXAMPLE, ONE PROJECT WILL CONDUCT MICROBIAL SOURCE TRACKING TO DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS AND IMPLEMENT MITIGATION MEASURES FOR STORMWATER TREATMENT TO REDUCE HUMAN HEALTH RISKS DUE TO RUNOFF AND DECREASE THE NUMBER OF BEACH CLOSURES IN THE CITY OF ASHLAND, WHICH ENHANCES PUBLIC ACCESS TO LAKE SUPERIOR. CREATING A LAKE SUPERIOR PROJECTS DATABASE WHICH WILL SUPPORT KNOWLEDGE SHARING ABOUT PAST, CURRENT, AND FUTURE NATURAL RESOURCE PROJECTS IN THE LAKE SUPERIOR BASIN. 

WEBSITE DEVELOPMENT FOR THE MILWAUKEE URBAN WATER TRAIL TO PROMOTE TRAIL USAGE BY INCREASING AWARENESS OF PUBLIC ACCESS SITES. 

ADAPTING THE WISCONSIN MASTER NATURALIST PROGRAM TO AN ONLINE HYBRID PLATFORM TO INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY TO THE PROGRAM AND INCREASE THE DIVERSITY OF THE MASTER NATURALISTS IN THE STATE.

CONDUCTING A COMPREHENSIVE SURVEY OF SHORELINE LITTER AND DEBRIS ALONG LAKE MICHIGAN IN DOOR COUNTY TO DEVELOP MITIGATION STRATEGIES FOR LITTER PREVENTION.

EXPANDING THE ASHWAUBOMAY RIVER TRAIL TO INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO FISHING AND OTHER RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES BY INCREASING ADA-ACCESSIBILITY OF THE TRAIL AND BRIDGE.
